text:
Apache 2.0.43, red hat 8.0, (gnu/linux-i386 2.4.18-14smp).

After unpacking the 2.0.43 distribution tarball, I did
  configure --enable-modules=all --with-layout=Apache

and was surprised that this did not actually enable all (at least
non-experimental) modules.  Same results with --enable-mods-shared=all.

I can see that it's desirable not to enable absolutely all modules; for
instance, choosing only one of cgi or cgid according to the mpm, only
including isapi under windows, suexec has potential security issues if
misconfigured, etc.

The modules I was surprised to find lacking from `all' were
deflate, cache, ext_filter, proxy, ssl, usertrack.

I looked at the documentation, searched google and the mailing list,
poked a bit at the source, emailed the users mailing list, etc., but
couldn't find any explanation.

(I already forged ahead by explicitly specifying --enable-ssl etc. to
configure, so that's fine, life goes on.  This is just to report the
issue for your consideration.)

Thanks,
karl@freefriends.org
creator: karl@freefriends.org

text:
Of "deflate, cache, ext_filter, proxy, ssl, usertrack" ...

if zlib is detected, yes, =all should enable deflate

cache is experimental.  

ext_filter *was* experimental, should now be enabled with =all.

proxy ... if 1.3 does so, we should enable that will =all as well.

ssl is a special consideration ... some jurisdictions have explicit laws
affecting what/how/who may use strong crypto.  *granted* it would require
detection of ssl, but still I suggest we want to leave that defaulted off.
(Calling that out in the docs, of course.)

And finally, there's no reason to to include usertrack with =all.

Just my 2c.
creator: wrowe@apache.org

text:
my system had zlib (configure reported it found), but deflate was not enabled.

proxy and usertrack -- unless there's a strong reason *not* to include them with
all, seems to me they should be, because hey, the user said `all' and not `most'.
(as an aside, it sure would be nice to be able to see a list of available
modules and whether they were included with all/most/neither.)

for ssl, i see your point.

thanks for the reply.
creator: karl@freefriends.org
jerenkrantz@apache.org
text:
Due to the fact that enabling proxy without explicit approval might be troublesome to some, I think we should leave it as 'no' - requiring explicit awareness of proxy availability.

mod_deflate is now 'most' (but probably won't be backported to 2.0).
When mod_ext_filter was moved out of experimental, it was set as 'most' as well.

Thanks for using Apache HTTP Server!

creator: zofa@wyer.org
text:
--enable-mods-shared=all also doesn't

In this case, since further action is needed to activate the module, can we just
build them all?

The questionable motivation for this is that distros tend to package apache with
everything built as a module, but the latency for security fixes can be quite
high. This would make it easy for people to build a clean apache.org tree and
have it work with their existing config, without having to spending an hour
finding all the extra --enable-foo=shared flags needed to get it to work.
